container.heading: Maryland AIDS Drug Assistance Program: Pharmacy Services

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)” means the medical condition caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.

“Drug” means an article intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and covered by the Maryland AIDS Drug Assistance Program as specified in Regulation .04 of this chapter.
“Enrolled in MADAP” means that an applicant has been approved to receive Maryland AIDS Drug Assistance Program benefits.
“Health care practitioner” means any individual licensed to prescribe U.S. Food and Drug Administration-approved drugs or other products in the state in which they practice.
“Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)” means the virus that causes AIDS.
“Maryland AIDS Drug Assistance Program (MADAP)” means the program administered by the Department that provides services specified in Regulation .04 of this chapter for enrolled recipients.
“Medical Assistance” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.09.24.02.

“Open formulary” means all U.S. Food and Drug Administration-approved prescription medications and related devices that are not on the list of excluded drugs and other products maintained by the Department according to Regulation .04-1 of this chapter.
“Pharmacist” means an individual registered and licensed to practice pharmacy in the state where the prescription is filled.

“Pharmacy” means an establishment or institution registered and licensed to dispense U.S. Food and Drug Administration-approved drugs or other products to the public in the state in which the establishment or institution is located.
“Preauthorization” means an approval required before the dispensing of the prescription.

“Prescription” means a direction, usually written by a health care provider authorized to prescribe drugs and other products and sent to the pharmacist for the preparation, dispensing, and directions for use of a drug or other product not excluded from the open formulary.
“Recipient” means an individual who is enrolled in MADAP.

section.heading: License Requirements.
section.text: The license requirements for participation in MADAP are the same as those for the Medical Assistance Pharmacy Services Program set forth at COMAR 10.09.03.02.

para.text: To participate in MADAP, a pharmacy shall:
Be enrolled in Medical Assistance, be a mail order company that accepts payments from the Department, or submit a request for exception to, and receive approval from, the Department;
Accept payment by the Department as payment in full for the professional services rendered and make no additional charges to the recipient or the recipient’s family;
Maintain records in accordance with standards established by Medical Assistance;
Maintain prescriptions for a minimum of 5 years and make them available for inspection, upon request, to the Department or its designee;
Provide services without regard to race, color, creed, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, marital status, or disability; and
Bill the recipient’s third-party insurance payer in accordance with the payer’s requirements in order to reduce the cost to be paid by the Department.
A pharmacy may not:
Knowingly employ a person who has been disqualified from Medical Assistance; or
Place a restriction on a recipient’s right to select a pharmacy of the recipient’s choice.
The recipient shall obtain a prescription for each drug or other product ordered for the recipient.
The Department shall pay for a prescription drug or other product not excluded from the open formulary if the prescription is ordered and signed by a health care practitioner for the recipient.
Maintain a list of drugs and other products excluded from the open formulary; and
Make available electronically the list of drugs and other products excluded from the open formulary.
A pharmacist may not dispense more than a 100-day supply of a prescribed drug or other product.
The Department may not pay for:
A drug or other product prescribed as part of a recipient’s care in a correctional institution, inpatient hospital, nursing home, or long-term care setting; or
Drugs or other products excluded from the open formulary, unless the Department grants the recipient preauthorization.

section.heading: Preauthorization Requirement.
section.text: A pharmacist shall obtain preauthorization for each prescription or refill before dispensing a drug or other product marked as restricted.

para.text: Except as provided in §§B and C of this regulation, the Department shall pay a pharmacy in accordance with the procedures of the Medical Assistance Pharmacy Services Program set forth at COMAR 10.09.03.07.

If the Department or the recipient tells the pharmacy that the recipient has or may have third-party insurance coverage to offset some or all of the cost for services provided under MADAP, the pharmacy shall:
Bill the third-party payer the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge for the services provided; and
Bill the Department for the difference between the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge and the anticipated third-party receipts.

If the recipient has third-party insurance coverage, the Department shall pay the pharmacy the difference between the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge and the anticipated third-party insurance receipts, not to exceed the amount permitted under COMAR 10.09.03.07F and G.

The Department shall make payments related to MADAP in accordance with any applicable policies and procedures for the administration of federal funds issued pursuant to the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Treatment Extension Act of 2009, and any subsequent modifications to the Act.

section.heading: Recovery and Reimbursement.
section.text: The Department shall follow the same procedures for recovery and reimbursement as the Medical Assistance Program in COMAR 10.09.03.08.

section.heading: Cause for Suspension or Removal and Imposition of Sanctions.

para.text: If the Department determines that a pharmacy or the pharmacy’s employee, or both, has failed to comply with federal or State laws and regulations, the Department may:
Suspend the pharmacy from MADAP;
Withhold payment to the pharmacy; or
Both.
Removal of a pharmacy or a pharmacy’s employee from Medical Assistance shall result in removal from MADAP.
The Department:
May consult with the State Board of Pharmacy regarding the actions of a pharmacy, such as:
A breach of confidentiality;
Refusal of service; or
Discrimination; and
Shall consider the findings and recommendations of the State Board of Pharmacy when deciding on the imposition of a sanction as stated in §A of this regulation.
The Department shall give the pharmacy written notice of the Department’s intention to impose sanctions referred to in §A of this regulation, including:
The effective date of the proposed action;
The reason for the proposed action; and
The pharmacy’s right to appeal the proposed action.
A pharmacy voluntarily withdrawing from MADAP or removed or suspended from MADAP according to this regulation shall notify a recipient that the pharmacy is no longer a MADAP pharmacy.

section.heading: Appeal Procedures.
section.text: A pharmacy filing an appeal shall do so in accordance with the Medical Assistance Program as set forth at COMAR 10.09.03.10.

section.heading: Confidentiality.
section.text: Unless otherwise authorized by law, the Department:

para.text: Shall keep all applicant and recipient personal information confidential;
May not disclose personal information kept on a recipient without written consent of the:
Recipient; or
Recipient’s parent or legal guardian;
Shall comply with the laws and regulations concerning the privacy and security of protected health information under:
Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA), 42 U.S.C. §§1320d et seq., as amended, the HITECH Act, 42 U.S.C. §§17932, et seq., as amended, and 45 CFR Parts 160 and 164, as amended, and their implementing regulations; and
Shall ensure that all interactive video technology-assisted communication comply with HIPAA patient privacy and security regulations.

section.heading: Availability of Funding and Program Termination.

para.text: If sufficient monies are not available to fund MADAP, the Department shall take the action necessary to eliminate a deficit which may include MADAP termination.
If MADAP is terminated, the Department shall provide benefits for each current recipient in accordance with COMAR 10.18.05.09B.
